reviewText:
Unfortunately, I've played all the Sakura games thus far, and while this one is the best one out of the three, it still fails to meet my expectations for a proper visual novel game.

The writing is a lot better, focusing more on dialogue and development of the story and characters, but even then, what they've done isn't great by any standard. The characters don't really stand out, and what little of their personalities we see aren't really touched on. The world isn't built up enough, simply going to the old 'World is in turmoil, and we live secluded in a city' plot, that, while it can be an interesting way to set up your story, it can fail hard when not given more depth. If the writer had taken more time to flesh out the chapter, then maybe it could've pulled it out of the blandness that it ended up becoming.

The art is better than before, giving characters more poses and backgrounds more of an immersive feel, but, overall, it's not really something we haven't seen done better by other developers with less of an art budget. Not to mention the CGs tend to leave something to be desired (and not just nudity, haha). They just seem a bit lackluster for what an artist can really do. They're the images that aren't bound by the need to be compatible with multiple poses and animation, so they can throw a lot more detail in, but they just go for the same amount that we can see in the character sprites, which is disappointing.

The sound/music isn't anything that we haven't heard before in the previous games, and it's not great, but not bad, either.

And do NOT get me started on visual novels that lack complex decision trees. THAT'S where the fun in playing them lies, because you feel the weight of your decisions firsthand, thus making you think about what you decide what to do next, rather than just 'pick your scene/heroine' gameplay, which can be interesting, if the writing and art can make up for it, but referring back to my previous statements, they don't.

Whenever I play one of the Sakura games, I always feel like I'm reading an anime, or rather that Winged Cloud really wants their visual novel to be an anime rather than a visual novel. Others can do it quite well (e.g. Steins;Gate), but if Sakura Fantasy were to become one by some extreme stroke of luck, it would be half-♥♥♥♥♥, even then.

The developers of the Sakura series need to seriously get their heads out of their asses, and learn from their mistakes, rather than producing more bland wastes of time that just put visual novel games in even more of a bad light than they already are.

All I'm glad for is that Steam refunds are possible, because this game isn't worth the money I spent to play it, and unless Winged Cloud manages to make something worth my time, I'll never purchase their games again, and I hope that no one else does either, because no person deserves to have to play through a game as boring as this.

I will just say this once. My favorite Sakura Game so far.

Sakura Fantasy Chapter 1
A yuri VN with choices that doesn't matter except to get all the CGs in the gallery. Well, here we are, a story about a kingdom suffering from some kind of invasion by dark nature, have you watch Naussica? Well, it's something like that. Somehow a disease has infected the land and is slowly eating everything in its way.

To stop this the Empress, kind of a authority figure, orders Raelin, a cadet in the forces of the empire, to embark herself and two of her friends, on a search for a fallen star that will help the empire restore its forgotten glory.

And that's it, that's the story of this chapter. We play as Raelin in her way to get the star while in the meantime get closer to her companions, and I mean really closer to them.

Pros.
- Art style (Sakura art style). Really nice done.
- Music. Is not that good but it isn't that bad either.
- Story. It's really interesting, and not that short as it seems.
- 18+ patch (I know you want it)

Cons.
- There is some content full of plot" that damage the story.
- No news on the second chapter for more that 9 months

This is my favorite one of the Sakura games and I'm really hoping for a second chapter. I recommend this on sale or at full price.

reviewText:
Sakura Fantasy Chapter 1 is the second VN of the Sakura series that I've reviewed. It has many interesting changes from other VN's in the Sakura series that are welcomed and make this VN unique. I'll cover some topics, such as the story, characters, and how well it presents the story and characters. TL:DR: It's a good read, lots more content than other Sakura VNs.

Story:

Our story begins with our protagonist, Raelin, struggling to wake up and get her armor on before morning formation at the military barracks she is staying at. From here we begin to learn more about the world and the various problems faced by humanity. There are individuals with powers called gifts, and Raelin's gift is the ability for Farsight, which allows her to see what others are doing or see specific areas. Her gift makes her the target for being called a pervert and we see more than once just what positives and negatives come from being able to spy on anyone. The story gives you many interesting elements and brings them together nicely, but the danger of the Mires really isn't pressed as much as I imagined it would. This however isn't a problem as it ties in well with just how unknown and strange the Mires really are. Since this is only chapter one the story ends on a cliffhanger, but it has a fantastic build up to that point and keeps the reader entertained rather well.

Characters:

Our main protagonist is Raelin, a young novice hoping to one day become a knight. Raelin, together with her best friend Gwynne and many other novices, is trained by Kiera, a knight with a dark past, and is constantly pushed to get better as a warrior. Raelin doesn't show any huge amounts of growth as a character since she isn't given any apparent shortcomings as we begin the VN, however this in no way means that she's a bland character, which has happened in other VNs from Winged Cloud. Gwynne is a different story however, while she's a very talented and smart individual she isn't as strong or as skilled as other novices when it comes to warfighting. While she improves on this regard it isn't the focal point of her character, she's very caring of Raelin and acts as a mother figure many times. Kiera, the instructor of the novices, is tough on her class. It's brought up many times that she had a pretty dark past, and we eventually learn why she is the way she is on her students. This was done nicely and she was definitely and interesting character to have in the story.

Presentation:

The visuals looks very nice and the *lewd* scenes are a welcome part. What I liked about this VN the most compared to other VNs from Winged Cloud is that we have a lot more options and our choices do have more impact, maybe that's why we have 50+ save slots. While we do have a lot more options they don't directly influence the outcome of the story but our interactions with other characters. Many people might believe that this is just the illusion of choice but it does play on the tradition" of the Sakura series that these choices are there for you to see who you consider to be "best girl." I would like to see actual story impacting choices in chapter 2 as well as the best girl choices we have now. I can definitely say I recommend this VN and hope you enjoy it as much as I did. I'm definitely looking forward to Chapter 2!"

reviewText:
OVERVIEWSakura Fantasy (chapter 1) is an almost all-female fantasy anime visual novel with erotic scenes. Being on Steam the scenes are very tame, but there is an adults-only patch available for free download if you're so inclined.

The protagonist is Raelin, a young female warrior-in-training with a special ability, farsight, that enables her to concentrate and observe events from a distance, unseen.

GraphicsThe scenes are nicely drawn, but often repeated, making the story seem even slower. The characters are beautiful, as you'd expect from Winged Cloud, but again, expressions and poses are often repeated, and the creative use of animation and movement seen in Sakura Angels is not quite as good here.

SoundMusic is acceptable, and sound effects few and far between. The game is almost entirely voiced in Japanese, though, which is great. I don't speak Japanese well enough to know if the voices are sticking to the dialogue, but they sound professional and akin to many an anime that I've seen in quality.

GameplaySakura Fantasy plays like any other visual novel: you read the story in a window at the bottom while looking at context-specific backgrounds and characters, sometimes complete with animations, on the rest of the screen. You make choices at certain points in the story for Raelin, the main character, and otherwise you watch and read. There's nothing new to the genre in Sakura Fantasy.

The story itself is quite slow and long winded. Raelin Raelin's friend, Gwynn, and teacher, Keira, are the most common characters you'll encounter, and they accompany her when the Empress sends Raelin on a quest into the wilderness.

Sakura Fantasy is an adult entry in Winged Cloud's lineup, however, and the story is interspersed with a number of graphical scenes of a sensual, if not sexual, nature, particularly when Raelin makes creative use of her special ability. I found most of these scenes fairly gratuituous, as if the plot took a quick sideline just as an excuse for another bathing scene, and they could have done with a bit more subtlety. But the art is nice.

PROS AND CONS
Pros:
+ Nice art featuring a host of attractive anime girls
+ Adult patch available, but not forced on you if you're not into that sort of thing
+ Trading cards

Cons:
- The story is fairly bland and takes a long time to actually get anywhere, and then it stops (end of chapter 1)
- Some poor writing and a number of grammatical errors
- No achievements, which would have been a great addition

CONCLUSIONSakura Fantasy (Chapter 1) is not as fun so interesting a story as some other visual novels on Steam, such as Winged Cloud's Sakura Angels.

I'm a fan of anime and enjoy visual novels, but there are better ones out there. I hope Winged Cloud improve the story for the next chapter. I still recommend Sakura Fantasy (Chapter 1) if you like anime visual novels, particularly if you enjoy a bit of gratuitious anime nudity and don't mind installing a patch.

6/10
